abstract.p: Bill Gates joins 15,000 Micosoft employees celebrating company's 25th anniversary at Safeco Field in Seattle, Wash (S)

block.p: Steve Ballmer jumped out of a giant birthday cake. And Bill Gates showed off a computer program he wrote in the Basic code language a long, long time ago for a video game (involving a car and a donkey) that seemed, well, more than a bit primitive today.
''It's very powerful,'' Mr. Gates said to a chorus of guffaws from a crowd of about 15,000 Microsoft employees last week. ''Honestly. This was really cool.''

The scene was Microsoft's 25th anniversary celebration last Tuesday, and Mr. Ballmer, Microsoft's chief executive, and Mr. Gates (does anyone not know that he was a co-founder of the company?) had rented out Safeco Field, the Seattle ballpark, for a companywide party. It was part retrospective celebration, part pep talk for a company that is both fighting for its survival against antitrust lawyers and embarking on a new strategy that will transform many of its products into Internet-based services.

But Sinbad, the actor, provided the most comic relief. He drew sustained laughter with his proposals for changing company procedures: ''No more e-mail,'' he urged. ''I mean, get up out of your chair and tell your co-workers what you want. No more being lazy. We could afford to close the company gym if we could get all of you to stop using e-mail.''
